Award.AwardTitle: Mechanics and Dynamics of Viscoelastic Metacomposites

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Metamaterials are microachitectured materials that exhibit unusual properties, such as negative apparent stiffness and density, not ordinarily observed. These exceptional properties allow realization of structural behavior that is not possible with conventional materials. One such possibility is suppressing or significantly damping the propagation of waves of certain of frequencies within a structure. This project investigates the possibility of realizing metacomposite materials that can suppress or significantly damp vibration, impact and blast loads by tuning the material microstructure and properties of its components. If realized, the innovation of this novel and unusual class of materials will result in very effective protection systems for civil infrastructure against hazards such as blast, impact and earthquakes. Additional areas of direct transformative impact of this research are vibration control of mechanical systems, energy harvesting and sensing. The PI will hold annual workshops for high school students and teachers to introduce them to the concept of simulation-based engineering.

The research will elucidate the fundamental relationships between time dependent viscoelastic properties of the constituents of acoustic metacomposite materials, its microstructural morphology and its wave mitigation characteristics under dynamic loading. This fundamental structure-property relationship is currently lacking for metamaterials that do not exhibit elastic response. The primary hypothesis of this project is that the interacting mechanisms of wave dispersion induced by the material heterogeneity and wave dissipation due to material viscosity can be employed to control and suppress wave propagation within large frequency bands(i.e., tunable bandgaps). Within this research, an efficient and accurate multiscale computational homogenization methodology for transient dynamic response of heterogeneous materials with material nonlinearity will be developed, and a comprehensive study on wave propagation and energy dissipation characteristics of viscoelastic metacomposites will be performed. Asymptotic analysis and the mathematical homogenization techniques will be used to formulate high order balance equations that can accurately capture nonlinear dispersion. Computational solution algorithms will be developed to accurately capture the emergence of bandgaps in multidimensional microstructures. These computational tools and algorithms will be employed to tailor the morphological makeup of a composite material for achieving superior wave mitigation property at targeted frequency ranges. The focus of the investigations is on core-shell particle-reinforced composites with dissipative,viscoelastic, constituents.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Wave propagation in architectured composite materials such as phononic crystals and acoustic metamaterials exhibit complex response patterns due to the interactions between the propagating macroscopic wave and the material microstructure. Controlling these interactions offer tremendous opportunities in many engineering applications, such as cloaking, acoustic diode and vibration control. In this research we have demonstrated that favorable properties could be achieved by considering material damping (i.e., viscoelasticity), which provides an additional degree of freedom in the design and tuning of the architectured materials. Additionally, design of these complex materials is usually a tremendous challenge from experimental standpoint as the interactions and the resulting response patterns are often complex and unexpected. In this project, we have also developed a modeling and simulation framework that would allow detailed prediction of the response of these materials at the scale of the material microstructure as well as at the scale of the structural application.  

In this project, we devised an efficient multiscale computational framework for the simulation of large-scale elastic and viscoelastic composite structures under transient dynamic loading conditions. We formulated nonlocal homogenization model that captures the effective dynamic properties of the composite materials, which effectively limits the need to resolve the intricate, fine scale features of the composite during the analysis, while accounting for the salient wave dispersion behaviors that occur at the microstructure scale. The proposed model effectively extended the capabilities of mathematical homogenization method, a popular multiscale modeling theory, to accurately predict short wave propagation in composites.

The proposed homogenization model has potential applications in analysis and design of many novel engineering devices that leverage the band-gap phenomenon, such as wave guides. In design of a wave guide, wave is allowed to propagate through certain desired path within a structure, while it is suppressed in all other directions. This behavior can be achieved by tailoring of the microstructures.

For instance, we simulated the behavior of composite metamaterial waveguides using the proposed homogenization models. In this application, wave propagation is effectively localized into a narrow band within the structure, where the wave is allowed to propagate. The wave is prohibited to propagate within the rest of the domain, leveraging the band structure of the composite material. The proposed model accurately predicts the overall harmonic wave field and captures the wave guide.

In addition to the above-mentioned research accomplishments, this project allowed for the training of a PhD student, who will be a productive member of the US workforce in this area of engineering for the years to come. Additionally, this project allowed for summer research experiences for an undergraduate student, who as a result of this experience, decided to pursue graduate education in the engineering field. This research also resulted in a number of high-quality archival research publications, presentations at universities, national and international conferences that disseminated the research outcomes to the scientific community. This research also affected the education of a broader group of graduate students, since the research outcomes was directly incorporated into a graduate level course that the PI teaches at Vanderbilt University.


Last Modified: 11/05/2018
Modified by: Caglar Oskay
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Wave propagation in architectured composite materials such as phononic crystals and acoustic metamaterials exhibit complex response patterns due to the interactions between the propagating macroscopic wave and the material microstructure. Controlling these interactions offer tremendous opportunities in many engineering applications, such as cloaking, acoustic diode and vibration control. In this research we have demonstrated that favorable properties could be achieved by considering material damping (i.e., viscoelasticity), which provides an additional degree of freedom in the design and tuning of the architectured materials. Additionally, design of these complex materials is usually a tremendous challenge from experimental standpoint as the interactions and the resulting response patterns are often complex and unexpected. In this project, we have also developed a modeling and simulation framework that would allow detailed prediction of the response of these materials at the scale of the material microstructure as well as at the scale of the structural application. In this project, we devised an efficient multiscale computational framework for the simulation of large-scale elastic and viscoelastic composite structures under transient dynamic loading conditions. We formulated nonlocal homogenization model that captures the effective dynamic properties of the composite materials, which effectively limits the need to resolve the intricate, fine scale features of the composite during the analysis, while accounting for the salient wave dispersion behaviors that occur at the microstructure scale. The proposed model effectively extended the capabilities of mathematical homogenization method, a popular multiscale modeling theory, to accurately predict short wave propagation in composites. The proposed homogenization model has potential applications in analysis and design of many novel engineering devices that leverage the band-gap phenomenon, such as wave guides. In design of a wave guide, wave is allowed to propagate through certain desired path within a structure, while it is suppressed in all other directions. This behavior can be achieved by tailoring of the microstructures. For instance, we simulated the behavior of composite metamaterial waveguides using the proposed homogenization models. In this application, wave propagation is effectively localized into a narrow band within the structure, where the wave is allowed to propagate. The wave is prohibited to propagate within the rest of the domain, leveraging the band structure of the composite material. The proposed model accurately predicts the overall harmonic wave field and captures the wave guide.
